query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita 2 mi ritrovai per una selva oscura, 3 ché la diritta via era smarrita.
query.result:
**English:**
1 In the middle of the journey of our life 2 I found myself in a dark wood, 3 because the straight way was lost.
**Old English:**
1 On middes wege ðæs lifes weges 2 ic me fand ðær on wudu dimme, 3 forðæm ðe rihte weg wæs forloren.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 Ahi quanto a dir qual era è cosa dura 5 esta selva selvaggia e aspra e forte 6 che nel pensier rinova la paura!
7 Tant’ è amara che poco è più morte; 8 ma per trattar del ben ch’i’ vi trovai, 9 dirò de l’altre cose ch’i’ v’ho scorte.
query.result:
**English:**
4 Ah, how hard it is to tell you what it was like, 5 this wild, savage, and harsh wood, 6 which renews fear in my mind!
7 It is so bitter that death is little more so; 8 but to treat of the good that I found there, 9 I will tell of the other things that I perceived there.
**Old English:**
4 Eala, hú ðearle hit is to secganne 5 ðeos wudu wilde and weste and strang, 6 ðe on ðam mode ða geðohtas awehte!
7 Swa he is bitre ðæt deð is lyt ðæs mare; 8 ac ðurh ðæt ðe ic ðær ðæt gode funde, 9 ic secge ða ðing ðe ic ðær geseah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Io non so ben ridir com’ i’ v’intrai, 11 tant’ era pien di sonno a quel punto 12 che la verace via abbandonai.
query.result:
**English:**
10 I do not know well how I entered it, 11 so full of sleep was I at that moment 12 that I abandoned the true way.
**Old English:**
10 Ne wot ic naðer hu ic ðær on com, 11 swa ic wæs mid slæpe gebunden 12 ðæt ic ðone rihtan weg forlet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Ma poi ch’i’ fui al piè d’un colle giunto, 14 là dove terminava quella valle 15 che m’avea di paura il cor compunto,
16 guardai in alto e vidi le sue spalle 17 vestite già de’ raggi del pianeta 18 che mena dritto altrui per ogne calle.
query.result:
**English:**
13 But after I had reached the foot of a hill, 14 where that valley ended 15 which had pierced my heart with fear,
16 I looked up and saw its shoulders 17 already clothed with the rays of the planet 18 that leads men straight on every path.
**Old English:**
13 Ac ða ic wæs to ðæs beorgæs fotan cumen, 14 ðær ðæt dene wearð to ende, 15 ðe me ær hreðre mid egesan,
16 ic uplocodan and ða geseah ðæs beorgæs eaxla 17 mid ðæs sunnan leoman beliden, 18 ðe ðone rædan weg ræð ofer eall.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Allor fu la paura un poco queta, 20 che nel lago del cor m’era durata 21 la notte ch’i’ passai con tanta pieta.
query.result:
**English:**
19 Then the fear was somewhat quieted, 20 which had lasted in the lake of my heart 21 the night that I passed with so much pity.
**Old English:**
19 Þa wæs ðære fyrhte feaum gemynd, 20 ðe on ðæs heortan mere mærde wæs 21 ða niht ðe ic ðurhferde mid swa micle efne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 E come quei che con lena affannata, 23 uscito fuor del pelago a la riva, 24 si volge a l’acqua perigliosa e guata,
25 così l’animo mio, ch’ancor fuggiva, 26 si volse a retro a rimirar lo passo 27 che non lasciò già mai persona viva.
query.result:
**English:**
22 And like one who with labored breath, 23 having emerged from the sea to the shore, 24 turns to the perilous water and gazes,
25 so my soul, which was still fleeing, 26 turned back to look at the pass 27 that no one living ever left.
**Old English:**
22 And swa swa se ðe mid geswincum breoste, 23 of ðam sæ ufeweard on ðone sand, 24 eft hwearfeð and ða wædole lagu 25 geond ðone sefan sweotole geseoð,
26 swa min mod georn, ðe ða gyt fleah, 27 eft hwearf ðurh ðone fæstenne weg 28 ðone næfre gumena ænig ofer eorðan 29 lifgende ne gestah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Poi ch’èi posato un poco il corpo lasso, 29 ripresi via per la piaggia diserta, 30 sì che ’l piè fermo sempre era ’l più basso.
query.result:
**English:**
28 After I had rested my weary body a little, 29 I resumed my journey through the deserted plain, 30 so that my firm foot was always the lower one.
**Old English:**
28 Þa ic ðone wergan lichomne reste hæfde, 29 ic eft ongunnon ða earfoðan gesecan, 30 swa ðæt min fot wæs symle ðe niðra.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Temp’ era dal principio del mattino, 38 e ’l sol montava ’n sù con quelle stelle 39 ch’eran con lui quando l’amor divino
40 mosse di prima quelle cose belle; 41 sì ch’a bene sperar m’era cagione 42 di quella fiera a la gaetta pelle
43 l’ora del tempo e la dolce stagione; 44 ma non sì che paura non mi desse 45 la vista che m’apparve d’un leone.
query.result:
**English:**
37 It was the hour of the beginning of the morning, 38 and the sun was rising with those stars 39 that were with it when the divine love
40 first moved those beautiful things; 41 so that the hour of the time and the sweet season 42 were a reason for me to have good hope 43 of that beast with the spotted skin;
44 but not so much that the sight of a lion 45 that appeared to me did not give me fear.
**Old English:**
37 Wæs ða morgentid and ðære sunne 38 up astigende mid ðam steorrum 39 ða ðe mid hire wæron ða ða ðæs Godes lufe
40 ærest gesceop ða wlitigestan gesceafta; 41 swa ðæt ðære tide and ðære sweartan tíde 42 wæs ic bliðe and blide mód hæfde 43 ðæs deores mid ðære gesprecladan hyde;
44 ac ða ðeah ðæt me ne wæs swa ðeah 45 ðæt me ne ondrysnede ðæs leones gesyhð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Questi parea che contra me venisse 47 con la test’ alta e con rabbiosa fame, 48 sì che parea che l’aere ne tremesse.
query.result:
**English:**
46 This one seemed to be coming toward me 47 with his head held high and with raging hunger, 48 so that it seemed the air trembled with it.
**Old English:**
46 Þes ðuhte ðæt hit wolde to me cuman 47 mid hafelan heafde and mid reðe mode, 48 swa ðæt ðæs windes blast ðær ða wordon cwæð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Ed una lupa, che di tutte brame 50 sembiava carca ne la sua magrezza, 51 e molte genti fé già viver grame,
52 questa mi porse tanto di gravezza 53 con la paura ch’uscia di sua vista, 54 ch’io perdei la speranza de l’altezza.
query.result:
**English:**
49 And a she-wolf, who seemed 50 laden with all cravings in her leanness, 51 and had already made many people live in misery,
52 this one caused me such heaviness 53 with the fear that came from her appearance, 54 that I lost hope of reaching the heights.
**Old English:**
49 And an wulf, ðe ðara womma gewilnode, 50 ðuhte ðæt heo wære mid hungre geðreatod, 51 and ða folc oft micle yrmðe geworhte,
52 ðeos me swiðe gedrefde mid ege, 53 ðurh ðone egesan ðe of hire gesihðe com, 54 ðæt ic ða hyht forlet ðæs uplican lifes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Mentre ch’i’ rovinava in basso loco, 62 dinanzi a li occhi mi si fu offerto 63 chi per lungo silenzio parea fioco.
query.result:
**English:**
61 While I was wandering in a low place, 62 before my eyes there appeared to me 63 one who seemed hoarse from long silence.
**Old English:**
61 Þa ic fór on ðam stede niðer, 62 þa wæs beforan minum eagum geworden 63 se ðe ðurh ða langsuman swigunge ðuhte dumb.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Quando vidi costui nel gran diserto, 65 «Miserere di me», gridai a lui, 66 «qual che tu sii, od ombra od omo certo!».
query.result:
**English:**
64 When I saw him in the great desert, 65 "Have mercy on me," I cried to him, 66 "whoever you are, a shade or a real man!"
**Old English:**
64 Þa ic ðone geseah on ðam widsæ, 65 "Miltsa me," ic cwæð, "gif ðu man sy," 66 "odðe hwæt ðu sy, ðu sceadu odðe scucca!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Rispuosemi: «Non omo, omo già fui, 68 e li parenti miei furon lombardi, 69 mantoani per patrïa ambedui.
query.result:
**English:**
67 He answered me: "Not a man, a man I once was, 68 and my parents were Lombards, 69 both of them Mantuans by birth.
**Old English:**
67 He andswarode me: "Nis nan man, man ic wæs iu, 68 and mine magas wæron Lombardas, 69 Mantuanas be æðele byrig."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 Nacqui sub Iulio, ancor che fosse tardi, 71 e vissi a Roma sotto ’l buono Augusto 72 nel tempo de li dèi falsi e bugiardi.
query.result:
**English:**
70 I was born under Julius, though it was late, 71 and I lived in Rome under the good Augustus 72 in the time of the false and lying gods.
**Old English:**
70 Ic wæs geboren under Iulio, þeah hit wære læt, 71 and ic lifde on Rome under þæm godan Augusto 72 on þæm timan þæra leasra and lygenra goda.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Poeta fui, e cantai di quel giusto 74 figliuol d’Anchise che venne di Troia, 75 poi che ’l superbo Ilïón fu combusto.
query.result:
**English:**
73 I was a poet, and I sang of that righteous 74 son of Anchises who came from Troy, 75 after proud Ilium was burned.
**Old English:**
73 Ic wæs scop and sang ðone rædne 74 Ancises sunu ðe of Troia com, 75 siððan ðæt sigefolc Ilium wearð 76 forbarn and forgrunden.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 Ma tu perché ritorni a tanta noia? 77 perché non sali il dilettoso monte 78 ch’è principio e cagion di tutta gioia?».
query.result:
**English:**
76 But why do you return to such distress? 77 Why do you not climb the delightful mountain 78 which is the beginning and cause of all joy?"
**Old English:**
76 Ac ðu hwi ðær ðu eft cymst to ðære earfeðnysse? 77 Hwi ne stihst ðu ðone wynsuman munt 78 ðe is anginn and ordfruma ealre blisse?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 «Or se’ tu quel Virgilio e quella fonte 80 che spandi di parlar sì largo fiume?», 81 rispuos’ io lui con vergognosa fronte.
query.result:
**English:**
79 "Are you then that Virgil, and that fountain 80 that pours forth such a broad river of speech?", 81 I answered him with a shamefaced brow.
**Old English:**
79 "Eart ðu ðonne se Virgilius and se wællstream 80 ðe ðurh ðinne muð spryngð swa micelne flod?" 81 ic him andwyrde mid afylledre heortan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 «O de li altri poeti onore e lume, 83 vagliami ’l lungo studio e ’l grande amore 84 che m’ha fatto cercar lo tuo volume.
query.result:
**English:**
82 O honor and light of the other poets, 83 may my long study and great love 84 that has made me seek out your book avail me.
**Old English:**
82 Eala ðu ðara scopa leohta and leoht, 83 freme ðe min lange geleornung and min micla lufu 84 ðe ðe geworhte ðæt ic ðinne boc sohte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Tu se’ lo mio maestro e ’l mio autore, 86 tu se’ solo colui da cu’ io tolsi 87 lo bello stilo che m’ha fatto onore.
query.result:
**English:**
85 You are my master and my author, 86 you alone are the one from whom I took 87 the beautiful style that has brought me honor.
**Old English:**
85 ðu eart min lareow and min auctor, 86 ðu eart ana ðe ic nam min agen ðanc 87 ðone fægran stīl ðe me hæfð to wurðmynte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Vedi la bestia per cu’ io mi volsi; 89 aiutami da lei, famoso saggio, 90 ch’ella mi fa tremar le vene e i polsi».
query.result:
**English:**
88 You see the beast for which I turned back; 89 help me from her, O famous sage, 90 for she makes my veins and pulses tremble."
**Old English:**
88 ðu gesihst ðone wilde deor ðe ic fram gewende; 89 gehealpe me ðu from hire, ðu hehsta hæleð, 90 forðon heo ða æddran me on innan ða breostan sticað."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Molti son li animali a cui s’ammoglia, 101 e più saranno ancora, infin che ’l veltro 102 verrà, che la farà morir con doglia.
query.result:
**English:**
100 Many are the animals to which she mates, 101 and more there will be yet, until the greyhound 102 comes, who will make her die in pain.
**Old English:**
100 Fela sindon ða deor ðe heo mid gewifad, 101 and ma gita sindon, oððæt ðe ðæt greghund cymð, 102 ðe heo ofslihð mid sare.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Questi non ciberà terra né peltro, 104 ma sapïenza, amore e virtute, 105 e sua nazion sarà tra feltro e feltro.
query.result:
**English:**
103 This one will not eat earth nor pewter, 104 but wisdom, love, and virtue, 105 and his nation will be between felt and felt.
**Old English:**
103 Þes ne cíebð næfre eorðan ne stán, 104 ac wisdom and lufe and mihte, 105 and his ríce bíð betwux felt and felt.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
106 Di quella umile Italia fia salute 107 per cui morì la vergine Cammilla, 108 Eurialo e Turno e Niso di ferute.
query.result:
**English:**
106 Of that humble Italy shall be the salvation 107 for which the virgin Camilla died, 108 Euryalus and Turnus and Nisus of wounds.
**Old English:**
106 Of ðære earman Itaille bið ðæt hælu 107 ðurh ða ðe ða mægð Cammilla wearð acweald, 108 Euryalus and Turnus and Nisus ðurh wunda.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Questi la caccerà per ogne villa, 110 fin che l’avrà rimessa ne lo ’nferno, 111 là onde ’nvidia prima dipartilla.
query.result:
**English:**
109 This one will hunt her through every town, 110 until he has sent her back to Hell, 111 from where envy first divided her.
**Old English:**
109 Þeos heo on elcum ceastre ceorran sceal, 110 oððæt heo heo on helle becume, 111 þanon heo ærest asundran com.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 In tutte parti impera e quivi regge; 128 quivi è la sua città e l’alto seggio: 129 oh felice colui cu’ ivi elegge!».
query.result:
**English:**
127 In every part he rules and there he reigns; 128 there is his city and his lofty throne: 129 oh happy he whom he chooses there!
**Old English:**
127 On ælce healfe he gewealdeð and ðær rixað; 128 ðær is his burh and his heahsetl: 129 eadig bið se ðe he ðær geceoseð!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 E io a lui: «Poeta, io ti richeggio 131 per quello Dio che tu non conoscesti, 132 acciò ch’io fugga questo male e peggio,
133 che tu mi meni là dov’ or dicesti, 134 sì ch’io veggia la porta di san Pietro 135 e color cui tu fai cotanto mesti».
query.result:
**English:**
130 And I to him: "Poet, I beg you 131 by that God whom you did not know, 132 so that I may escape this evil and worse,
133 that you lead me where you just said, 134 so that I may see the gate of Saint Peter 135 and those whom you make so sorrowful."
**Old English:**
130 And ic to him: "Þu sceop, ic ðe bidde 131 ðurh ðone God ðe ðu ne cuðest, 132 ðæt ic mæge fleon ðis yfel and wyrse,
133 ðæt ðu me læde ðær ðu ær sædest, 134 swa ðæt ic geseo ða geat of Sancte Petre 135 and ða ðe ðu macast swa sarige."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Allor si mosse, e io li tenni dietro.
query.result:
**English:**
136 Then he moved, and I kept behind him.
**Old English:**
136 Þa he fór, and ic him æfter folgode.
